continued to feed himself, gradually increasing

as penduous So those of the Hottentot wo
men His weight at the tnle he was put undc

ces are or record OF those who have exceeded

woman whose history is given by Guns, weigh


ed 1872 pounds, Ahrcns, $50, and our country
; man, Edward Bright, the fat man Of Essex, IS h

This patient, krocker, was rescued from h.
immediate danger by copous and trequc

I Purgative medicines were frequently given,

: the iodine being found very much TO acce.rat

, time the history otthc case was concluded (Ar

The following is an abstract the h4aory Of
a case Of enormous obesity, which affords some
curious and interesting physiological facts, and
may se've TO warn folks Of the danger ofexces-
sive eat;ng;-


Krocker (of Rcrlin)-for that was the fellows
name, did not, like Bright, Ahrens, Clay, and
other truly great personages, signaze himself
much in his youth, but was content to eat and
drink the same quantity of food as his neigh.
hors. About the age of thirty he began to give
way to a disposition to devour immense masses
of meat, and the more he ate, the more his APP
petite increased until his time was consumed in
little else than eating and sleeping. His occu-
patton was that of butcher, and animal food
was his favorite repas, contrary to the usual hab
its Of such people. -Krocker, however, would
devour from eight to ten pounds of triPe at a
meal, or from six to seven pounds of beef and
sausages. He continued in this way to stuff
himself. gradually becoming fatter, until it re-
quired siIeen pounds of beef daily, to satisfy his
hunger! For bet he has frequently dcvoured
the boiled flesh of az, entire csLfin day, season
ed only with SALT in the presence of many per.
sons; and on one occasion he declared himself
ready to attack second, but could get no body
to bet against him. He could not trust himself
in the sausage mandatory, as he would eat the
minced meat by the pound, spreading it over
bread with as little ceremony as the people
spread treacle. By way of breakfast, or supper,
he would clean from two to three dozen of the
pettitoes of pigs; and it appears, at last, to have
puzzled his friend TO know how to supply him.
His usual drink was beer, of which he daily
drank from two to th<as quarts In this way he

81 would suppose him To be New Englander"


One Of Ir WDuGie's Constituents.


Mr.. ETNor: Who is New Englander9
will answer the question. He is "A de.
scendant Of the Pilgrims who preferred
death to bondage, who, for the sake OF ci-
vii and religious liberty, left the splendid
abodes Of slavery, hraved the dangers Of the
ocean, and fixed their residence among the
savages in the wilderness. These same
Pilgrims under the auspices of Liberty, pa
tiently endured every privation, and tri-
umphed over every danger. They wrest-
ed the tonahawk from the hand of its cruel
possessor, and turned the wilderness into
fruitful fields.


Who is a New Englander? One who has
been taught from his infancy, the strictest
rules of morality and religion; viglantly to
guard his own, and equally to respect the
rights Of others; through his own enterprise
and industry he seeks independence; he cul-
tivates his farm with his own hands, and
lives by the sweat OF his face, he is Fl ee and
happy--doubly happy, in the freedom and
happiness of all around him.


Who is New Englandeil He is we'll
known in every country and in every cline:
he makes the produce Of the ocean add to
the riches OF his Country; he gathers wealth
amidst the SHOWS and ice of the Polar re-
gons; for him Arabia yields her spices; his
ships navigate every sea. and return richly
treighted with the produce Of India and If
the Isles of the ocean; his Enterprise is pro-
verbal from the Arctic to the Antartic cir
Gle. .


WHO'S a New Englander? Ask at home,
who has introduced the arts and sciences
amongst youf Who has raised and d.corat
ed the lofty temples that adorm your city,-
! Who has cuI.ch"S-. (. Lv h,lng its stares
Irom the .igugiu Ciyunicir.

The sacred ship" the Chancellor. Captain
Baker the first slip despatched from New York
by the benevolent and patriotic friends OF Greece,
has arrived below that port from Gibraltar She
brings, as We understand, dispatches from Mr.
Miller, who went out in her as the Agent OF the
Committee for the Greek Fund raised in that
city, and in the vicinity. The editors OF the y.
York Statesman received from Mr.. Miller pri-
vate letter, of which the following is copy.


Mn Dear Sri have again arrived on these
once classic shores and have commenced my
pleasing, ifnot celestial employment, of distrb-
uting the liberal donations OF my countrymen 10
the suffering Greeks. Alas. could the sensible
and happy daughters Of my own dear country,
know what their sex suffer here, they would
even forget their ornaments and be induced to
send the proceeds Of them to cover the naked
ness of those who once were 'as soft rs the roses
they twined," but are now reduced to the most
abicct want. The frigate Hope has been in sew
crsl engagements already, in one Of which she
received eleven balls in her works, without hav
ing one man killed.

MORE TROUBLE IN COLOMBIA.


The brig Athenian arrived on Friday

present himself to Congress, and take the

state of affairs 10 the South of the Republic,
brought on by the invasion OF Bustamcnti' S
division, and the decided appreciation his
conduct has received from the Vice Presi-
dent Santander, have made it necessary for
the President to detach a strong force under
the orders of Gen. Salon against it, which
| force has marched from this place. Anoth-
er strong division has marched from Vene-
| zuela, under the command of Gen. Pacz
and from Maracaibo, Gen. Urdaneta march
cs at the head of another division, which has
| already arrived at Ceuta, on his way to Bo'
gotta and the southern departments. The
public Indignation is now directed against
Santander, whom we have been taught
to believe almost the only genuine republic
an left--a man who stood forth fcsrlessly il
the breach between Bolivar and despotlsu
while Bolivar is lauded to the skies, San

divon-vith having speculatcd upon thu

Nessre. Editors: The instrument for
pumping poisonous substances from the
stomach was used last week, we understand,
by the physicians of this town with the most
complete success.


1t was employed on gentleman who had
swallowed prodigious dose OF muriate OF
mercury or corrosive sublimate and laudan.
nm, aud that too, four hours after the poison
had been swallowed, and after he had been
in state Of commissions and total insensbll-
ity, for at least two hours He was in
deep state of inscnsiblity when the tube
was introduced into the stomach. A pint
and a half oi lime water, the antidote TO the
poison, was first injected, and it was pleas
ing to witness the immediate good etects.-
1t was suffered to remain few minutes;
and even before it as Withdrawn from thc
stomach the convulsion had ceased, and the
patient articulated several words as ols-
tnctly as the apparatus in the mouth would
permit, and nationally.
The lime water injected was as llmplc
and as pure as lime water always is; but
when it was pumped ont it had assumed the
orange color testing the presence OF murls's
of mercury. This test, however, was un"
necessary, as quantity of the poison that
had not Been swallowed. proved the nature
of it. We are happy to state that the pa
tient has recovered from the effects Of this
dose


We the more readily publish this case be-
CAUSE we are rather inclined 70 believe that
this NAV have been the first instance IN
| in which the instrument has been employed
in this state. And as we understand that
the operation is so easy both to the operator
and the patient, we cannot but think 1t We
ry important that the employment OF
should be widely extended. Melanchely
instances of poisoning are but too frequent
| The actions Of poisons are often so SPEEDY
aud the discovery of having swallowed tneH,
is frequently so late, as totally to exc!uue "'i
relief by swallowing remedies, III cohse'
quence of the insensbility of the patient,
1 This operation is the only resource lett; ahu
! it is consolation to know that it is so very
practicable and so etficacicus. II CH'-eF'

Wellesly Pole has denounced the Duke


of Wellington; in the London newspapers.


in the following terms:


"When the proper opportunity arrives,
J shall have no hesitation in declaring, in the
most formal manner. my objections to his
Grace the Duke of Wellington, not only be-
: coming the guardian of my children, but my
strong feelings of indignation at his Grace,


in either not publicly coming forward, upon
oath to declare my unhtness to exercise my
parental rights, or supporting me, in the
struggle am making, for the restitution Of
) these rights; but, on the contrary, allowing
his name to be used upon all occasions, viz
in the Masters Office, in the court Of Chan
! Gerry, and in society, as sanctonins those
. proceeding which have for their object the


destruction OF my honor: whilst his Grace's


correspondence and conversation Tpth me


set forth his great anxiety to promote NJ,

continued to feed himself, gradually increasing
in bulk, his breathing becoming daily more diifl-
cult, and his power Of locomotion daily dlinin-
ishing, until he was at last obliged to conhne
himself to his large chair and his bed. Every
now and then he was i'll great danger OF suftoca-
ton; and it was on one of those OCCASIONS that
Graefc, who has related the IN one OF the re-
cent numbers of his Journal, was called to HIN.


He found the man stretched out upon beds
complaining of very difficult respiration, TO
such an extent, as to express his fear OF being ab-
solutely choaked. His lips were Of dull violet
color, his eyes appearing to start from ms heau'
the conjunctivai lining being Of = bright red CO.
lor the entire countenance was OF dark GRIM,
SOM and the pulse was trcmulous, irregular, ana
frequently intermittent. lie complained also OF
great pslpitation Of the heart; although. from,
the immense projection of the abdomen, and
the huge pendulous breasts, it vas impossible
to bring the hand upon the part OF the chest
covering it. He could only speak at intervals,
and that with great difficulty. The abdomen
protruded, so as to cover the upper halt oi the
thights; and on several parts OF its immensely
dstended surface were round reddish spots, OF
about the fourth ofan inch in diameter, hard and
painful to the TOUCH somewhat resembling small
iipoma or fatty tulnours Although the cham
ber liz which lie lay was kept very clean, and his
linen frequently changed, the odeur exhalee
WAS exceedingly offensive, and resembled muct
the smell OF dissectng room, or butchers
shop on the evening of hot day. krocker wa.
five feet four inches high; the circumference Of
his abdomen was feet inches, the circumfcr
ence of his thigh feet inches, of the calf O
his Leg, l foot inches; his breasts measured
one foot eight inches in circumference at then
bases, and were eight inches long, being almos


as penduous So those of the Hottentot wo
men His weight at the tnle he was put undc


Craefc's care, Was about 400 pounds; but I'M


mense as this weight may appear, other nstan


ces are or record OF those who have exceeded


it. The fat man OF Lceuwarden, who Was ez
hbted before the medical faculty OF Ieydeu


and taken about from place to place IN iiolian'


in boat as u show, Weighed sos pounds; th'


woman whose history is given by Guns, weigh


ed 1872 pounds, Ahrcns, $50, and our country
; man, Edward Bright, the fat man Of Essex, IS h


was commonly called, weighed SIX hundred an


sixteen pounds.


This patient, krocker, was rescued from h.
immediate danger by copous and trequc
bleeding, by large doses ofcalome and the s
stituton of fasting for his enormous siu'llno =
I Purgative medicines were frequently given,


strictly vegetable diet and vegetable acids, wer
: ordered; and, in about four weeks he was reduc
y ed to about $40 pounds. IN the space OF tou
4 months, dnrng the half Of which time he tool
large doses Of iodine, with occasional pnigativ.
: the iodine being found very much TO acce.rat


absorption, he was reduced to 267 pounds, an
enloyed good health; was active, cheerful, au
! able to resume his former business At th
, time the history otthc case was concluded (Ar
gust 10, 1920 he was reduced to 2O9 pounds


his health being good, and his appetite mode

full articles.headline:
REMARKABLE CASE. OF ENORMOUS


OBESITY
full articles.article:
The following is an abstract the h4aory Of
a case Of enormous obesity, which affords some
curious and interesting physiological facts, and
may se've TO warn folks Of the danger ofexces-
sive eat;ng;-


Krocker (of Rcrlin)-for that was the fellows
name, did not, like Bright, Ahrens, Clay, and
other truly great personages, signaze himself
much in his youth, but was content to eat and
drink the same quantity of food as his neigh.
hors. About the age of thirty he began to give
way to a disposition to devour immense masses
of meat, and the more he ate, the more his APP
petite increased until his time was consumed in
little else than eating and sleeping. His occu-
patton was that of butcher, and animal food
was his favorite repas, contrary to the usual hab
its Of such people. -Krocker, however, would
devour from eight to ten pounds of triPe at a
meal, or from six to seven pounds of beef and
sausages. He continued in this way to stuff
himself. gradually becoming fatter, until it re-
quired siIeen pounds of beef daily, to satisfy his
hunger! For bet he has frequently dcvoured
the boiled flesh of az, entire csLfin day, season
ed only with SALT in the presence of many per.
sons; and on one occasion he declared himself
ready to attack second, but could get no body
to bet against him. He could not trust himself
in the sausage mandatory, as he would eat the
minced meat by the pound, spreading it over
bread with as little ceremony as the people
spread treacle. By way of breakfast, or supper,
he would clean from two to three dozen of the
pettitoes of pigs; and it appears, at last, to have
puzzled his friend TO know how to supply him.
His usual drink was beer, of which he daily
drank from two to th<as quarts In this way he

THE NEW ENGLAND CHARACTER


NINDIC ATED.

81 would suppose him TO be a New Englandern


One of.ur; .NDuGie's Constituents.
full articles.article:
81 would suppose him To be New Englander"


One Of Ir WDuGie's Constituents.


Mr.. ETNor: Who is New Englander9
will answer the question. He is "A de.
scendant Of the Pilgrims who preferred
death to bondage, who, for the sake OF ci-
vii and religious liberty, left the splendid
abodes Of slavery, hraved the dangers Of the
ocean, and fixed their residence among the
savages in the wilderness. These same
Pilgrims under the auspices of Liberty, pa
tiently endured every privation, and tri-
umphed over every danger. They wrest-
ed the tonahawk from the hand of its cruel
possessor, and turned the wilderness into
fruitful fields.


Who is a New Englander? One who has
been taught from his infancy, the strictest
rules of morality and religion; viglantly to
guard his own, and equally to respect the
rights Of others; through his own enterprise
and industry he seeks independence; he cul-
tivates his farm with his own hands, and
lives by the sweat OF his face, he is Fl ee and
happy--doubly happy, in the freedom and
happiness of all around him.


Who is New Englandeil He is we'll
known in every country and in every cline:
he makes the produce Of the ocean add to
the riches OF his Country; he gathers wealth
amidst the SHOWS and ice of the Polar re-
gons; for him Arabia yields her spices; his
ships navigate every sea. and return richly
treighted with the produce Of India and If
the Isles of the ocean; his Enterprise is pro-
verbal from the Arctic to the Antartic cir
Gle. .


WHO'S a New Englander? Ask at home,
who has introduced the arts and sciences
amongst youf Who has raised and d.corat
ed the lofty temples that adorm your city,-
! Who has cuI.ch"S-. (. Lv h,lng its stares

and were actually dying liz the streets OF

lament, and every other treacherous trans
action to destroy General Bolivar and keep


himself and MS nirnydons in power.

full articles.headline: FROM GREECE.
full articles.article:
The sacred ship" the Chancellor. Captain
Baker the first slip despatched from New York
by the benevolent and patriotic friends OF Greece,
has arrived below that port from Gibraltar She
brings, as We understand, dispatches from Mr.
Miller, who went out in her as the Agent OF the
Committee for the Greek Fund raised in that
city, and in the vicinity. The editors OF the y.
York Statesman received from Mr.. Miller pri-
vate letter, of which the following is copy.


Mn Dear Sri have again arrived on these
once classic shores and have commenced my
pleasing, ifnot celestial employment, of distrb-
uting the liberal donations OF my countrymen 10
the suffering Greeks. Alas. could the sensible
and happy daughters Of my own dear country,
know what their sex suffer here, they would
even forget their ornaments and be induced to
send the proceeds Of them to cover the naked
ness of those who once were 'as soft rs the roses
they twined," but are now reduced to the most
abicct want. The frigate Hope has been in sew
crsl engagements already, in one Of which she
received eleven balls in her works, without hav
ing one man killed.


| Lord Cochranc is moo on cruise with tho
| frcate and one steam vessel. Report says, thai
| he has had an engagement with the Turkish fri
gates in the mouth of the Gulph Of Lepanto
and that he obliged the Turks to retire. The
steam vessel has lately burnt Turkish eorvett,
with hot shot. As both the frigate and thu
steam vessel have good furnaces Oh board,


hope that they do even more execution than
anticipated.


/ am, truly yours, J. P. MILLER


island Of Poros, jane lst, 1897

MORE TROUBLE IN COLOMBIA.


The brig Athenian arrived on Friday
evening from Carthagena, brings adyiccs
from 3ogota down to August, and letters
from Caithagcna to the 18th. The intern
al troubles of the Republic were increasing
again. A letter to the Editors Of the Ca
zette, states that Bolivar left Carthagena on
the 2Sth of July, on his way to Bogota, to
present himself to Congress, and take the
oath required by the Constltntion.-rheb bad
state of affairs 10 the South of the Republic,
brought on by the invasion OF Bustamcnti' S
division, and the decided appreciation his
conduct has received from the Vice Presi-
dent Santander, have made it necessary for
the President to detach a strong force under
the orders of Gen. Salon against it, which
| force has marched from this place. Anoth-
er strong division has marched from Vene-
| zuela, under the command of Gen. Pacz
and from Maracaibo, Gen. Urdaneta march
cs at the head of another division, which has
| already arrived at Ceuta, on his way to Bo'
gotta and the southern departments. The
public Indignation is now directed against
Santander, whom we have been taught
to believe almost the only genuine republic
an left--a man who stood forth fcsrlessly il
the breach between Bolivar and despotlsu
while Bolivar is lauded to the skies, San
tander is now charged with being the insti
gator of the rebellion of Bustamenti and hi
divon-vith having speculatcd upon thu
public funds, &c.


One letter says, that since the attempt a
the revolution, (whose direction has beel
attributed 10 Santander.) he has lost mucl
good opinion even amongst his most stead
fast partizans. 1t may be and that bis par
ty has been actually reduced to a few des
perate and despicablc we'll known charac


ters. Another letter states, that the tw
frigatcs built in this country are laid up, an

Nessre. Editors: The instrument for
pumping poisonous substances from the
stomach was used last week, we understand,
by the physicians of this town with the most
complete success.


1t was employed on gentleman who had
swallowed prodigious dose OF muriate OF
mercury or corrosive sublimate and laudan.
nm, aud that too, four hours after the poison
had been swallowed, and after he had been
in state Of commissions and total insensbll-
ity, for at least two hours He was in
deep state of inscnsiblity when the tube
was introduced into the stomach. A pint
and a half oi lime water, the antidote TO the
poison, was first injected, and it was pleas
ing to witness the immediate good etects.-
1t was suffered to remain few minutes;
and even before it as Withdrawn from thc
stomach the convulsion had ceased, and the
patient articulated several words as ols-
tnctly as the apparatus in the mouth would
permit, and nationally.
The lime water injected was as llmplc
and as pure as lime water always is; but
when it was pumped ont it had assumed the
orange color testing the presence OF murls's
of mercury. This test, however, was un"
necessary, as quantity of the poison that
had not Been swallowed. proved the nature
of it. We are happy to state that the pa
tient has recovered from the effects Of this
dose


We the more readily publish this case be-
CAUSE we are rather inclined 70 believe that
this NAV have been the first instance IN
| in which the instrument has been employed
in this state. And as we understand that
the operation is so easy both to the operator
and the patient, we cannot but think 1t We
ry important that the employment OF
should be widely extended. Melanchely
instances of poisoning are but too frequent
| The actions Of poisons are often so SPEEDY
aud the discovery of having swallowed tneH,
is frequently so late, as totally to exc!uue "'i
relief by swallowing remedies, III cohse'
quence of the insensbility of the patient,
1 This operation is the only resource lett; ahu
! it is consolation to know that it is so very
practicable and so etficacicus. II CH'-eF'

Jo.eph Hewes, of North Carolina, sue
eessful merchant, bred quaker, died VIXEN
attending Congress, 1779.


George Taylor, Of Pennsyivan'a--on ar
irving in America from Ireland. bound nm
self for a term of years az a common iaoor-
sr. at the Iron Works at Durham, on the
Delaware near Easton, was made CLERK 10
the works, the proprietor dying, ne eSpoused
his widow, and finally became himsrif the
cwner ofthe whole, amassed large fortune
pot into the provincial Assembly, mem
ber of business Nothing more recoHected
Of him in the vicinity or his residence, than
that ..he was fine man and furious Wing.
John Hart, of New jersey--a farmer
surnamed 'honest John" had never held
public office, when he was chosen delegate
10 Congress, his farm pllaged and destroy
ed by the Hessians, his biography possesses
peculiar interest, as very edlty'ng MUS
tration of the character ana course OF an
American yeoman.


Lewis Morris, of New York--a gentleman
farmer, a large landed proprietor, his whole
domain laid waste and ruined by the enemy
had three gallant sons in the field, the cele-
brated Governor Morris his halt brother.
William Elery, of Rhode lsland-a well
educated LAWYER, an elderly revolutionary
pariot. very useful member of Congress
throughout the war. "He otten," says his
hioprapher, "spoke of the signing OF the
declaration of dependence, and he spoke
uf it as an event which may be regarded
with awe, perhaps with uncertainty, but
not with fear" tle used to relate that he
had placed himself beside the Secretary,
Charles Thompson, and eyed each delegate
closely as lie affixed his name 10 the docu-
ment, and he saw dauntless resolution IN
every countenance. Elery dlea without
pain. at the age Of 95, sitting upright in his
bed and reading Tuly's Offices in Latin.
"of no di,tenper, ofno blast he died


But fell ike autumn fruit that menow'd long;
Fy'n wonler'd at because he falls no sooner
Fac seem'a TO wind him up for tourscore years;
Yet lie shy ran he on for iwel,c winters morei
Till ike ac lock worn out with eating time,
The wheels OF weary life at last stood STILL

from Connectcut; well trained physician;
81, useful member Of Congress; made great
sacrifices. governor of Georgia, 1888.


Oliver Walcott, Of Connecticut--a grad
uate Of Talr College; captain in the army

malor geaeral OF militia, aided il corquerine

cs Of the Supreme Court ct New Jersey,

my, and committed to the Cohmon Jail o.

Washington to interfere in his behalf and

Button Gwnnet, of Georgia, originally a
merchant, became a planter, an enthusas'
tic rebel. president of provincial Council
killed in duel with general M'lntosh. lr
l777, at the age Of As.


Joiah Bartlett, Of New Hampshire, sue
cessful practitioner of medicine; leading
whig in his province, commanded a reg
ment, the first who voted in Congress io
the Declaration, and the second who signet
1t, chief justice Of New Hampshire. the frs
Republican governor ol that state


Philip Livingston OF New York, one G
the committee of FIVE appointed to prepar
the Dec tlaration Of independence, gradu
ate of Yale College, q prosperous and hon
ored merchant, Conspicuous member {
the provincial legislature, speaker, die
while attending congress, in 1878, marty
to his public zeal.


Roger Sherman, Of Connecticut, also on
Of the committee Of FIVE, apprenticed to
shoemaker, and pursued the business unit
after he was twenty-two years of age, tray
elled on foot with his tools, gaining liyeli
hood; nourished his mind by various read
ing; kept :; country store, turned surveyor
applied himself to the law, acquired prsc
iice and fame; member o. the Albany con
vention ef lisa, judge of the superior cour
Of Connecticut twenty v-three years; mentbe
of congress for the opening Of the srst
1774. down TO the period Of his death,
1913; Ct great authority and usefulness;
member Of the convention that framed tn
present constitution of the United State
took considerable and Influential part
the dtbate, senator in Congress, a shrew
and ready writer, logo II debator; mode
Of Lrobit} discretion and steatlfastntss,
much revered as any patriot ot the times.-
HIS biography is full Of Instruction, but pr,
lix to tediousness

Wen all Of us shortly be doom'd
To part with our plain understanding,
For Intellect now has asSund


An attitude truly commanding!
All ranks are so ,lrca,iiuly wise,
Common sense is set quite At defiance,
And the child for It's porrdsc that cries,
Must cry in the language of Sctence.


Sing, tol dc rol lol, sc.
The Wearer it surely becomes,


TO talk OF his webs involntion,
For doubtless the hero of thrums

He speaks Of supply and demand,
lth the airs ot great legislator,
And almost cantell you of land,
That the smaller is less than the greater.


oiiiS, toi NC ioi iol, cNs
The 7ailor in cutting his cloth,


III speak Of the true comic section,
And no tailor is now such Goth,

Though wc know that he's only fractioni

The BlacbShtuh midst cinders and smoke,

with the air of practical chemist;
Poor Vulcan has recently got
lingo that's almost historic,

Because it is fli'd with coloric


Sing, tol de rol lol, &c
The Mason. in hook learned tone,
| Describes in the very best grammar
| The resistance that dwells in the stone,


And the power that resides in the hammer,
For the son Of the trowel and nod


Locks as big as the frog in the fable,
While lie talks in .iargon as odd


AS his brethren the builders ofBabel!


Sing, tol dc rol lol, &c.
The CoJler who sits at your gate,

Though the very same cobler OF late


o'er his work used TO sing and to whistle;
But cobbling's paltry pursuit
For a man of polite education
His works may be trod under foot,


Yet he's one Of the Lords of Creation.
| Sing, tol de rol lol, &c.
, Oh! learning's very fine thing
J. 1t almost is treason to doubt it
Yet many Of whom could sing,
Perhaps might as we'll be without it.
And without it my days will pass,
For to me it was neer worth dollar.
And don't wish to look like an ass
BY trying to talk like Scholar,
Sing, tol de rol lol, &c.

Wellesly Pole has denounced the Duke


of Wellington; in the London newspapers.


in the following terms:


"When the proper opportunity arrives,
J shall have no hesitation in declaring, in the
most formal manner. my objections to his
Grace the Duke of Wellington, not only be-
: coming the guardian of my children, but my
strong feelings of indignation at his Grace,


in either not publicly coming forward, upon
oath to declare my unhtness to exercise my
parental rights, or supporting me, in the
struggle am making, for the restitution Of
) these rights; but, on the contrary, allowing
his name to be used upon all occasions, viz
in the Masters Office, in the court Of Chan
! Gerry, and in society, as sanctonins those

destruction OF my honor: whilst his Grace's


correspondence and conversation Tpth me

The Kentucky Election has resulted in favour
of Jacksoni giving him seven members out OF
twelve.

ElNSEf JOHNS, Esq. was nominated by
the Federal Conferees, from the three counties,
assembled at noyer, ON the 7,h August, for the
House of Representatives, in the place of Louis
MI.anc Esd. Mr.. Johhsis friendly to the pre-.
sent Administration,


The friends Of General Jackson in the federal
party, not liking the above nomination, called
meetings aud appointed Conierees 10 meet at
Dover and nominate Jackson Candidate The
Contcrtcs met on the 29sh ult. and nominated
JAMES A. BAYAHD, Esq. as Representative to
Congress


The candidate nominated for the same Office,
blythe Democratic party, is Dr.. ARNOLD NAU-
DA!N, who Is friendly 10 the Administration
Here, likewise, the friends Of Gen. Jackson, re-
fused 10 support the regular candidate, and BY
contcrces, have nominated IiENEY WHITE
LEY, Esq. There are now four candidates
both parties having divided; viz;

eraI candidates, one foy Adams and the orther for
Jackson.

cratic candidates-une for Adams and the other
for Jackson

cline the nomination; in which case Na'idain and
Whitclcy will be the two opposing candidates.
